;;这张由研究人员提供的照片显示了科托布鲁斯拉斯克鲁塞斯生物站的一只皇家捕蝇鸟哥斯达黎加，2018 年 3 月。（J. Nicholas Hendershot，美联社）;
;

;哥斯达黎加的一项研究显示，拥有遮挡阳光的天然树木和森林的小农场可以为一些鸟类提供庇护所

;

;18 年来，鸟类专家 James Zook 一直在收集在这个中美洲国家的农场和天然森林中发现的近 430 种;热带;鸟类的记录。

;

; >;

;虽然鸟类在天然雨林中表现最好，但祖克说，一些通常在森林中发现的;物种;可以在“多样化农场”中建立种群。多样化农场是指包含类似于天然森林环境的区域的农场。

;

;“耕作方式很重要，”尼古拉斯·亨德肖特 (Nicholas Hendershot) 说。他是斯坦福大学的环境科学家。他帮助撰写了最近发表在《美国国家科学院院刊》上的研究报告。;

;

;“在这些多样化的农场中，您会看到具有特殊需求的鸟类物种的长期增长， “亨德肖特说。这些特殊需求包括供鸟类建造家园的安全和受阳光照射的保护区以及不同种类的食物来源。

;

;这种农业与工业化农业或只种植菠萝或菠萝等一种作物的农业有很大不同。他说，种植了香蕉。

;

;Natalia Ocampo-Penuela 是加州大学圣克鲁斯分校的环境科学家，她没有参与这项研究。她说，如果不进行研究，这些发现似乎也有意义。但她补充说，很少有来自热带地区的长期详细数据表明多样化农业可以支持某些森林鸟类种群。

;
;;;这张由研究人员于 2023 年 9 月提供的照片显示了哥斯达黎加科托布鲁斯芬卡的一个多元化农场。 （Gretchen C. Daily，美联社）;
;

;“通过 18 年的数据，你可以表明该物种;持续;在该地区，而不是简单地路过，”她说。

;

;在多元化农场发现的 305 个物种中，75% 在研究期间表现出;稳定;或不断增长的种群数量。其中包括像项圈巨蜥这样的鸟类，以及侏儒鸟家族的一些成员，这种色彩斑斓的鸟类以其复杂的交配舞蹈而闻名。

;

;露丝·贝内特 (Ruth Bennett) 是史密森尼候鸟中心的科学家。她没有参与这项研究。她说，“记录了一些鸟类不仅去那里，而且留在那里并且数量不断增长，这是一个巨大的;贡献;，”

;

;尽管如此，如此安全的环境，作者警告说，这些被称为栖息地的区域并不能抵消利用天然森林建造大型工业农场造成的总体人口损失。祖克将大型菠萝农场比作“鸟类沙漠”。

;

;科学家们越来越多地表示，拯救物种需要关注受人类影响的地区，而不仅仅是未受影响的地区。

;

;奥坎波-佩努埃拉说，现代拯救物种的努力不仅必须发生在保护区内，而且还必须发生在农业区甚至城市内。她说，这些努力必须发生在至少有可能某些物种可以生活在那里的地方。

;

;我是格雷格·斯塔切尔。

;;教皇方济各9月18日在梵蒂冈会见俄罗斯驻梵蒂冈大使伊万·索尔塔诺夫斯基2023年。（梵蒂冈媒体/路透社讲义）;
;

;教宗方济各正式欢迎俄罗斯新任驻梵蒂冈大使。

;

;罗马天主教会领袖会见大使伊万·索尔塔诺夫斯基周一在梵蒂冈城，外交官提交了他的官方文件。

;

;索尔塔诺夫斯基将接替亚历山大·阿夫杰耶夫大使。 2022 年 2 月，即俄罗斯军队入侵乌克兰的第二天，阿夫杰耶夫在俄罗斯驻罗马大使馆会见了方济各。

;

;索尔塔诺夫斯基的访问是在俄罗斯外交部长谢尔盖·拉夫罗夫表示政府准备好与天主教会再次会面后不久进行的。乌克兰和平特使，红衣主教马泰奥·祖皮。

;

;“梵蒂冈正在继续努力。教皇特使很快就会返回（俄罗斯），”拉夫罗夫上周五表示。他在莫斯科讨论乌克兰问题时与一群外交官和大使发表讲话。

;

;祖皮于 5 月由教皇方济各任命。此后，他访问了乌克兰首都基辅，以及莫斯科、华盛顿特区和北京。

;

;起初，祖皮的努力似乎集中在一项旨在使入侵后被带到俄罗斯的乌克兰儿童团聚的计划上。乌克兰。不过，这位外交官在北京与中国官员会谈时还讨论了重启乌克兰黑海港口的谷物出口。

;

;当他返回意大利时，祖皮表示，他在北京的会谈取得了重要的想法分享。他还对拉夫罗夫关于第二次访问的评论表示希望。 6 月前往莫斯科期间，祖皮会见了俄罗斯儿童权利部长玛丽亚·利沃娃-贝洛娃 (Maria Lvova-Belova) 以及总统弗拉基米尔·普京 (Vladimir Putin) 的顾问。

;

;国际刑事法院于 3 月底对利沃娃发出了逮捕令-贝洛娃和普京。法院指控他们绑架乌克兰儿童。俄罗斯官员否认在战争期间组织过任何;强制收养;的行为。

;

;祖皮周末接受了意大利主教会议 TV2000 广播公司的采访。他表示，拉夫罗夫对第二次会议的开放态度“很重要，因为和平是通过;对话;以及寻找可能和必要的空间来实现的。”

;

;方济各在会议上遵循了罗马教廷的中立传统。试图与乌克兰和俄罗斯保持开放的谈判途径来解决冲突。

;

;我是布莱恩·林恩。

;;这张由辉瑞于 2023 年 9 月提供的照片显示了该公司更新的新冠病毒的单剂量小瓶成人疫苗。美国监管机构已批准辉瑞和 Moderna 更新的 COVID-19 疫苗。 （辉瑞，美联社）;
;
;
;
;

;美国卫生官员表示，大多数人今年应该接种更新的 COVID-19 疫苗。

;

;上周，美国疾病控制与预防中心 (CDC) 批准了辉瑞及其合作伙伴 BioNTech 以及 Moderna 更新的 COVID-19 疫苗。 Novavax 的第三种疫苗仍在研究中。

;

;;谁应该接种更新的疫苗？;

;

;美国卫生官员批准了成人和儿童注射疫苗六个月大。他们说，从 5 岁开始，大多数人即使从未接种过 COVID-19 疫苗，也可以接种一剂。年幼的儿童可能需要更多疫苗接种，具体取决于他们的 COVID-19 感染史和疫苗接种史。

;

;CDC 主任曼迪·科恩 (Mandy Cohen) 上个月表示，她预计每年都会像流感疫苗一样接种新冠疫苗。然而，并非所有医生都同意每个人每年都需要它们。

;

;Dr.范德比尔特大学传染病专家威廉·沙夫纳 (William Schaffner) 是疾病预防控制中心的顾问。他说，“如果你六个月大或更大，你应该接种流感疫苗。对我来说，这对预防新冠病毒也有好处。”

;

;另一位 CDC 顾问是保罗·奥菲特 (Paul Offit) 博士，他是佛罗里达大学的一所大学。宾夕法尼亚州传染病专家。他说，他认为高风险人群应该每年注射一次疫苗。奥菲特说，研究尚未表明更新的疫苗可以预防低风险人群感染疾病。

;

;在英国，英国政府疫苗委员会表示，只有 65 岁及以上的成年人和高危人群才会接受注射，因为他们最有可能受益。

;

;;注射会有效吗？;< /p>;

;与去年针对;原始;病毒和 Omicron ;变种;的攻击不同，更新后的攻击针对名为 XBB.1.5 的 Omicron 亚变种制药公司补充说，早期测试表明，更新的疫苗可以对抗最新的亚变体 BA.2.86。

;

;世界卫生组织 (WHO) 官员最近;所述 BA.2.86 已在多个国家被识别;，包括美国、瑞士、南非非洲、以色列、丹麦和英国。

;

;COVID-19 大流行的严重程度有所下降。但世卫组织总干事谭德塞表示，新的 COVID-19 变种表明该病毒仍然对世界各地的健康构成威胁。

;

;CDC 上个月表示，在一项研究中，只有 42% 的人表示，他们会或可能会接种新疫苗。然而，在一年前提供疫苗时，只有约 20% 的美国成年人接种了更新的疫苗，称为加强疫苗。

;

;医生希望有足够多的人接种疫苗，以帮助避免像去年那样再次出现“三重流行”。当时，美国医院表示，他们必须应对流感季节提前、呼吸道合胞病毒（RSV）增加以及冠状病毒病例再次突然增加的情况。

;

;今年，美国医院报告称夏季，COVID-19 患者数量小幅增加。但这个数字比前一年少了很多。官员们表示，早期接种疫苗或感染有助于预防严重疾病和死亡。但大多数美国人已经大约一年没有接种疫苗了。

;

;疾病预防控制中心表示，人们可以同时接种每年一次的流感疫苗和更新的新冠疫苗。该机构表示，效果或副作用没有差异。

;

;我是 Mario Ritter, Jr.

;;游客们在日本最高峰富士山的山坡上看到游客 3,776米（12,388 英尺），2023 年 9 月 9 日，日本富士吉田。（路透社/Mariko Katsumura）;
;

;在一个灰蒙蒙、多雨的周六，公交车不断抵达日本富士山的基站富士。巴士在商店和餐馆前释放外国游客。

;

;该区域看起来类似于一个;主题;;公园;。这并不是大多数日本人所期望的 3,776 米高山之下的景象。富士山被认为是一个重要的宗教地区。日本人因其完美平衡的形状而尊敬这座山。

;

;“嘿，这里禁止吸烟！”一名商店工作人员告诉一名穿着短裤、拿着一罐啤酒的男子。他站在红色的“鸟居”门前，该门标志着前方神道宗教中心的入口。

;

;富士山位于日本东部的山梨县和静冈县之间。它一直受到本地和外国游客的欢迎。

;

;但官员们表示，最近赴日游客的增加导致了严重的污染和其他困难。他们补充说，他们可能被迫采取极端措施。他们可能会通过限制尚未建成的公共交通系统来参观这座山的唯一方式来限制游客数量。

;

;“富士面临着真正的危机，”山梨县的泉政武 (Masatake Izumi)近日，相关负责人对记者表示。这是今年道路关闭前的最后一个周末。

;

;“这是无法控制的，我们担心富士山很快就会变得如此;没有吸引力;，没有人愿意攀登它，”他说。

;

;富士山十年前就被联合国教科文组织列为世界遗产，进一步提高了它的知名度。世界遗产地区是联合国保护的对人类具有巨大价值的地方。

;

;但列入世界遗产的条件是日本减少游客数量，减少游客对环境的破坏，并修复旨在为人类创造的人造区域。访客。

;

;但是，访客数量有所增加。 “斯巴鲁”是第五个也是最大的基站，今年夏天约有 400 万游客。与 2013 年相比增加了 50%。

;
;;;2023 年 9 月 9 日，游客在日本富士吉田市海拔 3,776 米（12,388 英尺）的富士山第五阶段的山坡上看到游客。（REUTERS/克里斯·加拉格尔 (Chris Gallagher);
;

;尽管清洁工、企业和志愿者付出了辛勤的努力，社交媒体上仍然充斥着关于肮脏的浴室和攀登路径上的垃圾的帖子。

;

;Izumi担心为世界遗产委员会提供建议的国际古迹遗址理事会 (ICOMOS) 可能会来寻求;更新;。

;

;“子弹攀登”是登山者尝试的地方登上日本最高的山峰观看日出，并于当天下山。官员们表示，这也是一个日益严重的问题。

;

;今年的救援请求总数为 61 起，比去年增加了 50%。静冈地区警方发现，非日本游客约占 25%。一名官员表示，由于气温寒冷或山高，大多数人装备简陋。山梨警方没有类似的数据。

;

;一位当地游客表示，必须实施限制。

;

;“任何日本人一生中至少想爬一次富士山，”前来探望的 62 岁柴崎淳说道。 “但这里太;拥挤;。进入有限可能是我们必须忍受的事情。”

; Mon, 18 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Letting Mosquitoes Bite You for Sciencehttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/letting-mosquitoes-bite-you-for-science/7266482.html
;;2023 年 9 月 17 日星期日 21:58:00 GMT;

;;盐湖城灭蚊区的一群青色蚊子以艾拉·伯兰罕为食2023 年 8 月 28 日星期一，盐湖城。 （美联社照片/Rick Bowmer）;
;

;现在是午餐时间。在美国犹他州盐湖城的实验室里，蚊子找到了埃拉·伯兰罕 (Ella Branham) 的手臂。

;

;“它们不是很有攻击性，而且;挑剔;食者，”伯兰罕说。她向玻璃罐中呼吸，以吸引昆虫到她呼吸中的二氧化碳。 “所以我会用我的手臂喂它们。”

;

;伯兰罕自愿让南美蚊子（称为 sabethes cyaneus）吸食她的血液。她这样做是为了帮助产卵并维持盐湖城灭蚊区的教育和研究群体。

;

;该区是盐湖城周围众多蚊子控制区之一。美国寻求控制世界上最致命的动物之一。随着气候变化创造出更温暖、更湿润的环境，预计蚊子数量将会增加。

;

;蚊子可以携带登革热、黄热病、基孔肯雅热和寨卡病毒等病毒。它们对亚洲和非洲的公共健康尤其构成威胁，但在美国受到密切关注。美国疾病控制中心表示，2022 年当地机构报告了 1,100 多例西尼罗河病毒病例。

;
;;;一群青蚊，因其羽毛状的附肢和彩虹色、血色而被称为桨腿美人。 2023 年 7 月 19 日，在盐湖城喂艾拉·伯兰罕 (Ella Branham)。蚊子健康与气候（美联社照片/Rick Bowmer）;
;

;大多数感染西尼罗河病毒的人没有;症状;。但对某些人来说，它可能会导致;呕吐、;发烧;;，在极少数情况下还会导致癫痫发作或脑膜炎。大约在过去 25 年里，美国各地报告了与西尼罗河有关的近 3,000 人死亡和超过 25,000 人住院治疗，其中大部分发生在 8 月份。

;

;今年德克萨斯州和科罗拉多州等州报告了西尼罗河死亡事件。人们还认为蚊子导致马里兰州、佛罗里达州和德克萨斯州的人们感染疟疾。

;

;阿里·法拉吉 (Ary Faraji) 是一位疾病专家，也是盐湖城灭蚊区的主任。他说，随着气候变暖，蚊子季节开始得更早，持续时间也更长。该学区过去每年在九月中旬关闭，但现在变得越来越晚。去年，直到 11 月底，地区工作人员仍在设置和检查陷阱。

;
;;;2023 年 7 月 19 日，盐湖城灭蚊区季节性病媒控制技术员埃拉·伯兰罕 (Ella Branham) 在检查跗库蚊。 （美联社照片/Rick Bowmer）;
;

;今年，工作人员估计 5 月份的蚊子数量是往年的五倍。盐湖城经历了异常多雪的冬季和多雨的春季，为蚊子;繁殖;留下了更多的水。

;

;这就是健康威胁的根源。雄性和雌性一生以糖或花蜜为食，雌性需要血液为卵提供营养。

;

;包括科学家和学生在内的工作人员使用无人机、船只和车辆来捕获、分类和测试蚊子对于病毒。他们的工作考虑了天气系统和人口增长等因素如何影响疾病的传播。法拉吉说，靠近蚊子的人越多，传播的机会就越高。他补充说，犹他州大盐湖周围的湿地地区存在问题。

;

;尽管蚊子很危险，但它对世界各地的生态系统也很重要。有些是;传粉者;或鱼类、鸟类和青蛙的食物来源。

;

;“我们努力保持平衡并抑制它们，以免它们对社区产生负面影响， ”法拉吉说。 “把它们拿走肯定会对我们的整个生态系统产生;负面;影响。”

;

;我是 Dan Novak。

;

;

;

; Mon, 18 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 NASA: Oxygen-producing Device on Mars Performed above Expectationshttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/nasa-oxygen-producing-device-on-mars-performed-above-expectations/7268878.html
;;2023 年 9 月 17 日星期日 22:05:29 GMT;
;;
;;美国宇航局喷气推进实验室的技术人员将 MOXIE 仪器放入毅力号火星车的腹部加利福尼亚州帕萨迪纳市的一张未注明日期的照片。 （NASA/JPL-Caltech/Handout via REUTERS）;
;

;美国航天局 NASA 表示，放置在火星上的一个用于产生氧气的装置在一系列实验中的表现比预期的要好。

;

;该系统称为 MOXIE。它旨在将从火星大气中捕获的二氧化碳转变或转化为氧气。该仪器通过称为电解的过程进行工作。这个过程利用极高的热量将氧原子从二氧化碳分子中分离出来。

;

;据 NASA 数据，二氧化碳约占火星大气的 95% ;报告;。其余大部分是分子氮和氩。分子氧仅占火星大气的 0.16%。

;

;但是未来人类对火星以及可能的其他行星的探索将需要大量的氧气供应。 NASA 表示，这种化学元素对于宇航员呼吸和生产火星表面发射所需的火箭燃料是必需的。

;

;NASA 资助了 MOXIE 演示实验。麻省理工学院 (MIT) 的一个团队创建了该设备。

;

;MOXIE 仪器由 NASA 的毅力号探测器或漫游车运送到火星。毅力号于 2021 年 2 月抵达红色星球。该设备是一个附在漫游车上的盒形仪器。

;

;NASA 于 2021 年 4 月报告了 MOXIE 系统的第一个结果。当时，航天局报道称该装置已成功将火星大气中的二氧化碳转化为氧气。在第一个实验中，MOXIE 一小时内产生了 5.4 克氧气。 NASA 随后进行了一系列额外的实验来测试该系统的有效性。

;

;在 ;本月早些时候发表的声明;，示范项目的领导者表示 MOXIE 已经完成了第 16 次也是最后一次实验。他们指出，该设备的“令人印象深刻的性能”已经证明可以从火星大气中捕获氧气。声明称，这种氧气“可以帮助为未来的宇航员提供可呼吸的空气或火箭;推进剂;”。

;

;NASA 表示，自毅力号着陆以来，MOXIE 已生产了总计 122 克的氧气在火星上。这个量大约是一只小狗10小时内呼吸的量。 While the amount of oxygen is small, it represented the first experimental capture of a natural resource from the environment of another planet.

;

;When working at its highest level of effectiveness, the instrument was able to produce 12 grams of oxygen in one hour. NASA says this is twice as much as its engineers first estimated the system could produce.

;

;The MOXIE team has also been measuring the purity of the oxygen the device produces. Overall, it has reported the instrument produced oxygen that was at least 98 percent pure.

;

;The latest experiments with MOXIE on Mars are designed to help NASA build a much larger version of the system. A full-sized device could be deployed on Mars in the future.

;

;A NASA explanation of the instrument states: “The goal of a Big MOXIE would be to make and store all the oxygen that the astronaut and their rocket would need for their ;mission; before they even launch.” Such a system would need to make between 2,000 to 3,000 grams of oxygen per hour, the space agency noted.

;

;Trudy Kortes is the director of technology demonstrations at NASA Headquarters in Washington DC She said the agency was pleased to be able to support such a technology. “By proving this technology in real-world conditions, we've come one step closer to a future in which astronauts 'live off the land' on the Red Planet,” Kortes said.

;

;MIT's Michael Hecht leads the MOXIE development operation. He said in a statement the team's work will next center on working on the larger version of MOXIE. In addition, scientists will need to create equipment to liquefy and store the produced oxygen.

;

;I'm Bryan Lynn.

;

;

;

;;Bryan Lynn wrote this story for VOA Learning English, based on reports from NASA and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ;

; Mon, 18 Sep 2023 06:07:03 +0800 Calvin Coolidge: Silenthttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/americas-presidents-calvin-coolidge/4027250.html
;;Sat, 16 Sep 2023 21:58:00 GMT;

;;Calvin Coolidge: Silent;
;

;

;

;VOA Learning English presents America's Presidents.

;

;Today we are talking about Calvin Coolidge. He was the vice president under ;Warren Harding;. When Harding died suddenly a little more than two years into his term, Coolidge became president.

;
;;;Calvin Coolidge's 1924 campaign slogan was "Keep Cool with Coolidge.";
;

;Coolidge is linked to two opposing ideas. The first idea is quiet restraint.

;

;The president's nickname was “Silent Cal.” He rarely took part in ;casual conversation;. And as a leader, he often thought the best action was not to take any action.

;

;Many voters liked his “cool” style. Coolidge quickly earned a public image as a serious man who did not spend money or words easily.

;

;But Coolidge is also linked to a period in US history known as the Roaring Twenties.

;

;In those years, the 1920s, the American economy was generally good. Many people spent money on exciting things – such as the still-new automobile – and on entertainment, including alcoholic drinks, cigarettes, and dancing. Creative expression such as jazz and Art Deco architecture became popular.

;

;Calvin Coolidge is often given credit for helping fuel the Roaring Twenties with his pro-business economic policies.

;

;But some historians ;;caution;; against remembering Coolidge's business freedom policies too ;fondly;. They say he helped create the conditions for the severe economic depression that followed his presidency.

;

;;Early life;

;

;Calvin Coolidge and his sister were born and raised on a farm in the northeast state of Vermont.

;

;Coolidge spoke highly of both his parents.

;

;His father owned a store, and also held local political offices. He had a public image for honesty, public service, and ;thrift;.

;

;Young Calvin Coolidge helped his father in the store, and hoped to be just like him.

;

;Coolidge also admired his mother's strong character. He was 12 years old when she died, and he wrote that losing her was “the greatest ;grief; that can come to a boy.”

;

;Six years later, his sister also died.

;

;Their deaths made young Calvin Coolidge even more serious than he already was.

;

;But Coolidge was also known for his ;wit; – a kind of humor that often depends on word play or intelligence. As a student at Amherst College in Massachusetts, Coolidge became known as an able and funny public speaker.

;

;That skill helped him rise in politics. He began with lower-level offices in Massachusetts, and later served as that state's governor.

;
;;;President Calvin Coolidge and Grace Coolidge;
;

;

;

;​Along the way, he married ;Grace Anna Goodhue;, a teacher for the deaf. She was known to be warm and social, and the couple were reported to have a loving marriage. They went on to have two sons.

;

;In 1920, the Republican Party nominated Coolidge to be its vice presidential candidate. In general, voters liked the Republican ;ticket;. They were ready for a change after the reform policies and international ;engagement; of Democrat ;Woodrow Wilson;.

;

;Sure enough, the Republicans won the election in a landslide.

;

;But Coolidge did not enjoy the office of vice president very much. He had little power in the government. During meetings, he often remained silent.

;

;One summer night he and his wife were on vacation in Vermont. His father, Colonel Coolidge, woke them up in the middle of the night with some dramatic news: President Harding had died.

;
;;;Calvin Coolidge taking the oath of office on August 3, 1923.;
;

;Reporters quickly gathered at the ;small farmhouse;. Colonel Coolidge had not put electricity in the house. So everyone watched by the light of an oil lamp.

;

;Colonel Coolidge was a public official. He used the family Bible and a copy of the Constitution to ;swear in his son; as the 30;th; US president.

;

;Then the country's new leader did a very ;sensible; thing: he went back to bed.

;

;;Presidency;

;

;President Coolidge believed in limited government, especially limited federal government. He permitted state and Cabinet officials to decide as many issues as they could.

;
;;;President Calvin Coolidge;
;

;Coolidge used his authority to ;focus; mostly on the country's economy.

;

;At the time he took office, the US was at the start of an economic ;boom;. Coolidge tried to ;maintain; that ;prosperity;. He did not ;regulate; businesses too much, and he sharply reduced taxes, especially on the wealthy.

;

;By nearly every measure, the economy grew.

;

;But the policies also widened the divide between rich and poor Americans, and put the country's economy in a risky situation.

;

;More and more people began to invest their money in the stock market. Some put their dollars in dangerous investments.

;

;And business owners produced more goods than most members of the public could really ;afford;. Increasingly, people borrowed money on credit to pay for ;luxury; goods.

;

;At the same time, the economic situation of many American farmers was getting worse. The weather had been unusually dry in some places. And the price of food was falling.

;

;Farmers asked the federal government for assistance. But Coolidge rejected several bills that might have helped them. The bills had other problems, Coolidge reasoned, and he did not think that the federal government should intervene in the situation.

;

;So the farmers continued to suffer.

;

;But most voters remained supportive of Coolidge. Even though the president was considered a quiet person, he spoke often on the radio, appeared in a talking film, met with reporters regularly, and posed in funny costumes for photographers.

;
;;;Coolidge had a public image as respectable and responsible. But he could also make voters laugh.;
;

;He easily won elected in 1924. Historians believe he could have won another term, too, in 1928. But Coolidge chose not to seek office.

;

;Some believed he was too saddened by the death of his teenaged son. Shortly after Coolidge became president, the boy had been playing tennis and slightly wounded his toe. The wound became infected. The infection spread to the boy's blood. A few days later, he died.

;

;Although Coolidge continued his presidency, he later said the joy had gone from the job.

;

;But when he decided not to seek re-election, he did not talk about his feelings. Instead, he simply wrote a note to reporters saying: “I do not choose to run for President in 1928.”

;

;His secretary of commerce, Herbert Hoover, was elected instead. Coolidge retired to his home in Massachusetts and led a quiet private life.

;

;;Legacy;

;

;President Coolidge was well-liked by most Americans. Later presidents – including Ronald Reagan – sought to follow some of his economic policies.

;

;But many historians have questioned those policies. They say that Coolidge did not pay enough attention to the situation of farmers. And they say the stock market was rising too fast.

;

;Seven months after Coolidge left office, the US economy collapsed.

;

;The country was still deep in the Great Depression when Coolidge passed away. He died – quietly, of course – during an afternoon nap at the age of 60.

;

;His will was but a single sentence.

;

;I'm Kelly Jean Kelly.

;

;

;

; Sun, 17 Sep 2023 06:07:04 +0800 “Icing on the Cake“ Is As Good As It Soundshttps://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/icing-on-the-cake-is-as-good-as-it-sounds/7265587.html
;;Sat, 16 Sep 2023 21:59:00 GMT;
;;
;;FILE - Cakes with different icing and flavors are for sale ahead of Valentine's Day in London, Britain, February 13, 2023. (REUTERS/Peter Nicholls);
;

;And now, ;Words and Their Stories, ;from VOA Learning English.

;

;On this program we explore English words and expressions. We give you examples and notes on usage.

;

;Today we talk about a ;delicious; ;dessert; made from flour, butter, sugar, and ;flavorings; such as vanilla, chocolate, or my favorite, coconut. We are talking about cake!

;

;Cake is a commonly served sweet treat at celebrations. And the word also appears in several English idioms.

;

;Back in 2022, we taught the idiom ;to have your cake and eat it too;. This means to have the best of both worlds. You do not have to choose between two good things. Another expression is ;a piece of cake.; This describes something that is very easy to do or finish.

;

;Because of all the sugar and butter, we probably should not eat too much cake. But it is so good! And sometimes having a lot of something good is better. That is the message of today's show.

;

;Most cakes are made up of two parts: the part made from flour and the sweet topping, or icing.

;

;Now, a cake without the sweet icing on top is already great. After all, it's made with lots of butter and sugar. It's sweet and satisfying. So, the icing is not really necessary. But it makes the cake extra special.

;

;;Icing on the cake;

;

;And that is the meaning of the idiom ;icing on the cake;. Something already good is made better by the addition of something else. If you describe something as ;icing on the cake; or ;the icing on the cake;, you mean that it makes a good thing even better, or sweeter!

;

;Let's hear an example.

;

;;She loves her new job and her new co-workers. So, getting her own parking spot was ;the icing on the cake;! She hates looking for parking. ;

;

;The idiom ;icing on the cake; has another meaning. It can be someone's greatest ;accomplishment ;or victory.

;

;Here is an example of that usage.

;

;;He had achieved the highest level of success in the company. So, his ;fancy; new title was simply ;icing on the cake;. ;

;

;;Cherry on top;

;

;We have another dessert saying that means about the same thing. Some cakes or ice cream dishes have a special topping: a sweetened cherry.

;

;So, if something is the ;cherry on top;, it is an addition that turns something good into something great!

;

;;The Taylors bought the house without even knowing it had a large garden in the back. That was the ;cherry on top; since they both love to garden.;

;

;Sometimes we use the 'cherry on top' when making an appeal for assistance.

;

;Let's say, I really need a friend's help. I might say, “Please help me! Pretty please with a cherry on top.” This specially worded appeal often does the trick and the help comes! But, just know that it can also make you sound a little ;desperate;!

;

;And that's all the time we have for this Words and Their Stories. Until next time … I'm Anna Matteo!

;

;

;

;

;

;

;“This is a huge issue,” said one college math professor.

;

;“This is ;significant; and deep,” said another.

;

;They were talking about their students who are still struggling with ;basic; math skills three years after the start of the COVID-19 pandemic.

;

;Most of the students are in their first or second year in college. But when the pandemic started in 2020, they were still in high school, learning algebra or early calculus.

;

;During the pandemic, many US schools closed to in-person classes and started teaching by video call. Education experts said they believed students would catch up.

;

;College professors said they hoped for a “;rebound;” by now. But it has not happened in most places.

;

;As a result, universities in the US are trying to find ways to fix the problem. Some offer summer math camps. Others called on students to learn from each other, a process known as “peer tutoring.” Still others offer basic math classes students can take while also attending classes such as calculus.

;

;Brian Rider is the head of the math program at Temple University near Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

;
;;;Temple University in Philadelphia, Thursday, May 23, 2019. (AP Photo/Matt Rourke);
;

;“It's not that they're unprepared,” he said. “They're almost damaged.”

;

;Rider said he hated to say that, but “they're so behind.”

;

;;One teacher's experience;

;

;Erin Vorke is a math instructor at Eastern Florida State College. Many of her students must take a math class to get a two-year associate degree and move on to a four-year college. Some are high school students who are getting college credit. She told VOA about her experience.

;

;She said some of her students did not get a good ;foundation; in math even before the pandemic started. Once they missed time in class, their troubles increased.

;

;“It's definitely become a lot worse since the pandemic. And what I've been told is that everyone was just being passed through while they were in high school…I have a lot of students who can't work with ;negative; numbers, I have students who don't know what an ;even; number is.”

;

;Vorke said she cannot stop her class to teach students something they should have learned when they were in middle school.

;

;“I slow down as much as I can, but I have to cover my ;curriculum;,” she said.

;

;;Students struggling;

;

;Diego Fonseca is a student in northern Virginia, just outside of Washington, DC Nineteen-year-old Fonseca recently finished high school. This summer, he took a math “;boot camp;” at George Mason University so he could “;brush-up;” on math learning. He was one of about 100 students trying to improve their math skills.

;

;He said he did well in physics and computer science while in high school, but he did not get good scores on a math placement test for college. He wanted to take calculus, but in three tries on the test, he did not get a good enough score. He was permitted to take the test four times and wanted to do better on his final attempt.

;

;He was not having trouble with the math he learned recently, but he did not learn algebra well early in high school when schools closed in 2020.

;

;“I didn't have a ;hands-on;, in-person class,” Fonseca said. He later said he had trouble with more difficult algebra.

;
;;;Diego Fonseca, left, and his fellow students uses their bodies to plot their location on a graph based on the number they are holding during a summer math boot camp session on Thursday, Aug. 1, 2023 at George Mason University in Fairfax. Va. (AP Photo/Kevin Wolf);
;

;The math troubles are a problem for students at universities across the US who want to study engineering and science. Many are being placed into low math classes, which means they are falling behind in their study programs.

;

;Colleges say the pandemic learning problems affected both reading and math, but math skills suffered more, and recovery has been slow.

;

;Maria Emelianenko is one of the math professors at George Mason. She said students are in difficult pre-calculus and calculus classes and they cannot add simple ;fractions;.

;

;Jessica Babcock is a math professor at Temple. She said she realized how big of a problem she had while grading a test last year. Nearly all her students missed what she thought was a simple question.

;

;“It was a striking moment,” she said.

;

;Babcock teaches a basic math class that includes material students should have learned in their first year of high school. Before the pandemic, it had about 800 students. But by 2021 there were almost 1,400.

;

;Education researchers say math is a “hands-on” subject and it was hard to teach with students learning from home. If students moved on to subjects like geometry or trigonometry without learning algebra, learning gaps could go unnoticed for years. In addition, they say parents have an easier time helping their children with reading than math at home.

;

;;'Many students gave up on math';

;

;Katherine Strunk is an education expert who now heads the graduate school of education at the University of Pennsylvania. She led a study that looked at learning problems in Michigan.

;

;She said minority students and low-income students had the most problems during the pandemic.

;

;“They're the ones who are going to suffer the longer-term ;consequences;,” she said.

;

;Babcock, the Temple professor, said many students gave up on math. They did not come for help and continued getting poor grades on tests.

;

;The problems made Babcock change her class this year. The class has discussions, making students more involved in the learning process.

;

;“We really want students to feel like they're part of their learning,” Babcock said.

;

;That kind of class, said Vorke, may be more helpful for students who wonder when they will use algebra or other math in the future. She is part of a group of educators at her college who teach what she called “real-world problems (students) can actually relate to,” each summer.

;

;“If you go shopping, and there's a sale, and you want to figure out how much you'll be paying for an item that's 10 percent off. That's algebra,” Vorke said.

;

;After the summer boot camp, Fonseca said he chose to start his college studies at Northern Virginia Community College. In two years, he can move on to George Mason. He recently took the placement test again. On his final attempt, he qualified for calculus.

;

;“I didn't have any expectation I'd do that,” he said.
